bibl.title: Report from Walter Reed to the Adjutant General, October 31, 1898

div1.p: Reed's station and duty report states that he was on a Board to investigate causes of the prevalence of typhoid fever, investigated buildings at Natural Bridge, Virginia, and was on duty as Curator of the Army Medical Museum during October 1898. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Report from Walter Reed to the Adjutant General, October 31, 1898
div1.opener:
All communications to this Office should be addressed “To the Surgeon General, U. S. Army, Washington, D. C.”
Subject: Station and Duty.
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
U. S. ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
Corner 7th and B Streets S. W.,
Washington, October 31, 1898 , 189 .
TO THE ADJUTANT GENERAL,
U. S. Army.
Sir:
div1.p:
I have the honor to report that during the month of October,
1898, I was on duty as follows: October 1 to Oct. 10 on Board investi-
gating causes of prevalence of typhoid fever under Par. 40, Special Orders
194, Adjutant General's Office, Aug. 18, 1898. October 18 to Oct. 25, in-
specting buildings of Natural Bridge, Va., under Par. 80, Special Orders
247, War Department, Adjutant General's Office, Oct. 19, 1898. Oct. 11 to
Oct. 22, and Oct. 26 to Oct. 31 on duty in the Surgeon General's Office
as Curator of the Army Medical Museum, in accordance with Par. 2, S.O.,
No. 153, dated Headquarters of the Army, Adjutant General's Office,
Washington, D.C. July 7, 1893.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, Walter Reed, Major & Surgeon, U.S. Army
Curator.
